G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: The amount in controversy is less than $50,000, placing this matter within the jurisdiction of the District Court Department pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and related provisions.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment in G.L. c. 186, § 14 is interpreted broadly to protect tenants from serious interferences with their tenancy, whether caused by acts or by negligent failures to act.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The court devotes several pages to interpreting G.L. c. 186, § 14’s “quiet enjoyment” language, expressly tying it to the common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment and its protection against “serious interferences” with tenancy. It emphasizes that liability can be based on the landlord’s conduct or omissions whose “natural and probable consequence” is interruption of the tenant’s rights, and holds that malicious intent is unnecessary and that at least reckless conduct suffices. This reflects a broad, tenant-protective reading that covers serious interferences caused by failures to act, not just affirmative acts.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy…. [M]ore recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights…. [M]alicious intent is not a condition of liability.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.proposition: A landlord’s “neglect or omission” that results in “any interruption of heat, hot water, electricity, gas, or other services” required by law or by the terms of the tenancy constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.support_reasoning: The case holds that a landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment when conditions that substantially deprive the tenant of quiet enjoyment are the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted, and that intent is not required. However, the opinion does not specifically address interruptions of heat, hot water, electricity, gas, or statutorily required services, nor does it articulate a rule framed in terms of “neglect or omission” to provide those services. It supports a broader, conduct-based standard for breach of quiet enjoyment, not the particular service-interruption formulation stated in the proposition.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.”

Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473, 478–480 (2004)
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts appellate courts have recognized that “substantial interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises” caused by the landlord’s failure to maintain essential services gives rise to liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14’s covenant of quiet enjoyment in terms of “serious interferences” and “impair[ment] [of] the value of the leased premises,” and applies that standard to a landlord’s long‑term failure to correct serious code-related defects (ventilation and moisture/odor) that substantially impaired the tenants’ use of the unit. The court holds the landlord liable under § 14 on those facts, which fits the proposition that substantial interference with use and enjoyment caused by failure to maintain essential services gives rise to § 14 liability.
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The implied covenant of quiet enjoyment guarantees tenants the right to be free from ‘serious’ interferences with their tenancies. See G. L. c. 186, § 14… A landlord violates G. L. c. 186, § 14, when its ‘acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises.’… Here, the judge found that the landlord knowingly rented the premises in a defective condition and failed to correct the ventilation problem — a serious code violation — for over nine years.… On these facts… we think that the judge was required to find a serious interference with the tenancy and substantial impairment of the character and value of the leased premises.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The landlord’s intent to harm the tenant is not required; a negligent failure to correct conditions that seriously interfere with the tenant’s enjoyment can constitute a breach.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion’s quiet-enjoyment analysis makes clear that a landlord’s liability does not depend on an intent to harm but can arise from failures to act that naturally and probably result in serious interference with the tenancy. The court focuses on the landlord’s conduct, including omissions, and holds that doing nothing (or inadequately responding) to conditions that seriously interfere with tenants’ use can breach the covenant, without any requirement of intent to injure. This aligns with the proposition that negligent failure to correct such conditions can constitute a breach.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy… In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions. Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716 (1977). Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: The landlord’s intent to harm the tenant is not required; a negligent failure to correct conditions that seriously interfere with the tenant’s enjoyment can constitute a breach.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 to require only negligent (or greater) fault, not intent to harm, and explicitly confirms that negligent failure to repair known conditions that interfere with quiet enjoyment can breach the covenant. The court reiterates and clarifies prior holdings that some degree of fault, including negligence where the landlord has notice and fails to act reasonably, suffices for liability under the quiet enjoyment statute.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: “In 1973, the statute was rewritten and the requirement of intentional conduct was eliminated… In Simon v. Solomon… we concluded… it was not necessary for a tenant to show malicious intent… Twelve years later, in Cruz… we… concluded that negligent conduct, conduct involving ‘some degree of fault,’ by a landlord could support the imposition of liability under § 14. We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ … Today we make clear… there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord….”}

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: The loss of hot water for an extended period, in violation of the State Sanitary Code and the implied warranty of habitability, can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the landlord’s non-delegable statutory duty to provide heat and hot water absent a written agreement, and it addresses breaches of the State Sanitary Code and implied warranty of habitability, but it does not address or analyze a claim for breach of quiet enjoyment. There is no holding that loss of hot water (even if code-violative and a breach of habitability) constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment, so the case does not provide authority for that specific proposition.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: “The State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.190 and 410.201 (1983), provides that the owner of a dwelling ‘shall’ supply heat and hot water ‘except and to the extent that the occupant is required to supply the fuel under a written letting agreement.’ … The plain and unambiguous language of the regulation indicates that a writing is required when the obligation to provide heat and hot water is transferred to the tenant.”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199–200 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Massachusetts law also implies a warranty of habitability in all residential tenancies, requiring that premises be fit for human occupation and conform to the State Sanitary Code.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: Although this is a concurring/dissenting opinion, it expressly agrees that Massachusetts should abandon caveat emptor and recognize an implied obligation in residential leases that premises meet minimum habitability standards defined by the State Sanitary Code and related statutes. The opinion advocates treating those statutory and code-based standards as implied terms of every residential tenancy, and the majority in Hemingway adopted an implied warranty of habitability doctrine; together they support the proposition that Massachusetts law implies such a warranty requiring fitness for human occupation and conformity to the State Sanitary Code.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: "Since 1960 dwelling units have been subject to the State Sanitary Code ... [which] fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation.... As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant ..."

McKenna v. Begin, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 168,.raw_text: McKenna v. Begin, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 168, 173–74 (1975)
McKenna v. Begin, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 168,.proposition: Massachusetts law also implies a warranty of habitability in all residential tenancies, requiring that premises be fit for human occupation and conform to the State Sanitary Code.
McKenna v. Begin, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 168,.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly adopts and applies the Hemingway rule that in any rental of premises for dwelling purposes there is an implied warranty that the premises are fit for human occupation, and it ties that warranty to compliance with the State Sanitary Code and related regulations. The court reiterates that this implied warranty applies broadly to residential tenancies, is non-waivable insofar as it is based on the State Sanitary Code, and requires that essential facilities remain in a livable condition throughout the tenancy. Thus, it supports the proposition that Massachusetts law implies a warranty of habitability in all residential tenancies requiring fitness for human occupation and conformity with the State Sanitary Code.
McKenna v. Begin, 3 Mass. App. Ct. 168,.relevant_excerpt: There the court stated, “[W]e hold that in a rental of any premises for dwelling purposes, under a written or oral lease, for a specified time or at will, there is an implied warranty that the premises are fit for human occupation. ‘This means that at the inception of the rental there are no latent [or patent] defects in facilities vital to the use of the premises for residential purposes and that these essential facilities will remain during the entire term in a condition which makes the property livable.’ … This warranty (in so far as it is based on the State Sanitary Code and local health regulations) cannot be waived by any provision in the lease or rental agreement.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: The District Court and Housing Court have repeatedly found that extended deprivations of essential services, including hot water, constitute a serious interference with quiet enjoyment and warrant statutory damages under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The case is a Housing Court appeal and does involve deprivation of an essential service (heat) and G.L. c. 186, § 14, but it does not state that District Court and Housing Court have ‘repeatedly found’ such deprivations to warrant statutory damages. Instead, the Appeals Court itself holds that failure to provide heat breaches quiet enjoyment and that the tenant is entitled to declaratory, injunctive relief and an assessment of damages and fees under § 14. The proposition overstates the case’s institutional and precedential scope and mentions hot water, which is not addressed here.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season…constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to (a) a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14; (b) an injunction ordering that heat be provided in compliance with the State Sanitary Code without limitation on the amount to be spent by the landlords for fuel; and (c) an assessment of damages and counsel fees under § 14.”
